Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have emerged as a promising alternative to Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) for energy storage applications, due to abundant sodium resources, low cost, and similar electrochemical performance. However, the large radius of Na+ and high molar mass compared to Li+, result in large volume strain during charge/discharge and low reversible capacity and poor cycling stability. Due to exceptional physical and chemical properties, graphene has attracted increasing attention as a potential anode material for SIBs. When integrated with other nanomaterials in electrodes, graphene can improve the electrical conductivity, accommodate the large volume change and enhance reaction kinetics. This paper provides a systematic review of recent progress in the application of graphene based anodes for SIBs, with a focus on preparation, structural configuration, Na+ storage mechanism and electrochemical performance. Additionally, some challenges and future perspectives are provided to improve the sodium storage performance of graphene based electrodes. Graphical abstract This review provides a comprehensive summary of the recent progress in designing graphene based anodes for SIBs, with a focus on preparation, structural configuration, Na+ storage mechanism and electrochemical performance. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Sodium-ion batteries Graphene Anode Porous graphene Heteroatom doped-graphene Graphene nanocomposites 1 Introduction Due to the increasing consumption and rapid depletion of fossil fuels such as petroleum, coal, and natural gas, sustainable development has become a critical approach to meet the needs of the present without compromising the needs of tomorrow. With growing concerns over unsustainable energy consumption and environmental degradation, major research studies are now focused on exploiting and utilizing renewable energies such as wind, geothermal and solar energy. For effective and widespread use of such renewable energies, efficient energy conversion and storage technologies are of paramount importance [1]. Among these applications, electrical energy storage plays a vital role in consumer electronics and transportation systems. Due to the ever increasing energy demand, electrochemical energy storage devices such as rechargeable batteries require high energy density with rapid charge-discharge rates. To meet the increasing demand for energy, the development of novel and efficient energy conversion and storage devices is of utmost importance. The rapid development in the automobile and energy sector has evoked an increasing demand for high-performance rechargeable batteries with high specific energy and power density. Recently, extensive research has been carried out to improve the energy output of rechargeable batteries to power hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs), electric vehicles (EVs) and grid-based energy storage systems (ESSs) [2]. For more than two decades, the Li-ion battery (LIB) has ruled the rechargeable battery market for portable devices and still remains as the top choice for EVs and HEVs. Nevertheless, with regard to its electrical performance, a substantial improvement is least expected as the performance of LIB has almost reached its theoretical limits [3,4]. In this context, Na-ion batteries (SIBs) have been regarded as one of the most promising energy carriers owing to its low cost, the abundance of sodium sources and high energy density, meeting the demands of large-scale electrical energy storage applications [5,6]. SIB consists of positive and negative electrodes of Na insertion materials and they are ionically connected by immersing inside an electrolyte, which is generally a sodium salt dissolved in a solvent (Fig. 1 ). The conventional copper (Cu) current collector is able to be replaced by an aluminium (Al) current collector since Na metal does not form an alloy with Al. Therefore, inexpensive Al is definitively a cost-effective alternative to Cu as an anode current collector for SIBs. The working principle of SIBs is analogous to LIBs, and contains the movement of Na+ from the positive electrode (cathode) to the negative electrode (anode) during charging, and back to the cathode during discharging. However, the practical application of SIBs is hindered due to low reversible specific capacity and poor rate capability that are ascribed to the change in electrochemical kinetics triggered by large ionic radius of Na compared to Li. The large sized Na+ leads to lethargic diffusion efficiency, high volume change and severe pulverization of anodes [7–9]. Moreover, it could result in an unstable solid-electrolyte-interface (SEI) which unfavourably disturbs the reversible capacity and cycle stability. Therefore, discovering electrode materials with high specific capacity and cycling stability with good reversibility is critical for future development of SIBs. Recently, carbonaceous materials [10–12], metal oxides [13,14] and alloying materials [15,16] have been explored as anode materials for SIBs. Among carbon-based materials, graphene has aroused growing attention as a potential candidate to achieve excellent battery performance due to its outstanding electrical properties and unique two-dimensional (2D) structure with high specific surface area. Graphene, a two-dimensional (2D) layer of sp 2 hybridized carbon atoms has evoked great excitement among the scientific community since it was isolated from bulk graphite by Novoselov et al. [17,18]. Extensive research has been carried out in relation to graphene and graphene-based materials during the past decade [19]. Furthermore, studies of graphene have even progressed from the laboratory to the industry, as the rapid development of this extraordinary material possesses huge potential for commercialization [20,21]. This review provides a comprehensive summary of the recent progress in the application of graphene as an anode material in SIBs, focusing on synthesis, structural configuration and electrochemical performance of various nanostructures. Furthermore, this review evaluates the relationship between the structure and electrochemical performance of the anode. Finally, the authors would present the conclusions and future perspectives on improving the sodium storage capacity to guide the future screening and design of graphene anodes with better performance. 2. Sodium storage mechanism of graphene The similarity in the operation of LIBs and SIBs has benefited the research and development of SIBs immensely. Several theoretical studies have been carried out to evaluate key elements of SIBs, such as equilibrium voltage and voltage profile [22], theoretical capacity [23], theoretical energy density [24], phase stability [22,25], Na ion diffusion kinetics [22,26]. By investigating the lithium and sodium storage behaviour of hard carbon, Dahn and Stevens proposed the “insertion-adsorption” mechanism where they demonstrated the similarity between lithium and sodium insertion mechanisms in carbon materials (Fig. 2 a) [27]. They considered the carbon structure as a “house of cards” model in which multiple layers are formed parallel to each other while others are randomly oriented generating nanosized micropore regions. According to the proposed mechanism, the sloping potential profile at high potential range is attributed to the insertion of Na+ or Li+ between parallel carbon layers, while the low-potential plateau is related to the adsorption of Na+ or Li+ into the nanopores of randomly stacked layers. However, some researchers found that this model could not be used to explain several experimental phenomena [28]. Cao et al. investigated the Na+ and Li+ insertion-extraction behaviour in hollow carbon nanowires (HCNWs) and suggested that electrochemical characteristics of Na+ in the low potential region are similar to Li+ insertion into graphite (Fig. 2b) [29]. According to their study, the reaction in the high potential range (0.2–1 V) is attributed to the charge transfer on the surface of graphitic clusters, while the reaction at low potential range (0–0.2 V) is ascribed to Na+ insertion in the interlayer of graphitic carbon. This is denoted as the “adsorption-insertion” mechanism. Their theoretical simulations further verified that Na+ can easily intercalate into layered carbon materials with an interplanar distance of a little above 0.37 nm. Ding et al. supported this mechanism by employing ex situ XRD data which showed that mean interlayer spacing of carbonized peat moss (CPM) expanded from 3.96 to 4.16 Å upon discharge from 0.1 to 0.001 V [12]. Zhang et al. investigated how the microstructure of hard carbon nanofibers (CNFs) affect its Na+ storage capabilities [30]. The CNFs were prepared by electrospinning and their microstructure was tailored by carbonization at various temperatures. According to their systematic study, the Na+ storage mechanism in CNFs was proposed as follows, (i) the uptake of Na+ by defect sites induced by heteroatoms, (ii) the adsorption of Na+ on disordered graphene sheets, corresponding to the sloping region between 1 and 0.1 V, and (iii) the mesopore filling which occurs at around 0.1 V. Li et al. prepared P-functionalized hard carbon with “honeycomb briquette” shaped morphology via electrospinning and investigated the connection between microstructure and electrochemical property [31]. From their systematic study, they found that functionalizing hard carbon with P significantly increases the capacity in the sloping region between 0.1 and 1 V and the plateau capacity of P-functionalized hard carbons is not dominant as the distance of interlayer has a weak growing tendency after P functionalization. Wu et al. [32] studied the Na+ storage behaviour of bio-mass derived hard carbon obtained from carbonization of lotus seedpots and the interlayer spacing and porosity were varied by controlling the carbonization temperature. High temperature (1400 °C) generated hard carbon with narrowed d-space (3.70 Å) and reduced pore volume, and thus failed to accommodate Na+ either from intercalation into the lattice or adsorption onto the pore surface. The structure and the morphology of carbon materials have a strong influence on the sodium storage performance. Generally, for most of the carbon materials, the Na storage mechanism is based on insertion and adsorption. The mechanism of Na+ intercalation into graphite layers with over 0.37 nm interlayer distance is driven by a diffusion-controlled intercalation process (DIP). Due to the large atomic size and sluggish diffusion ability of Na+, DIP does not contribute to the high rate capacity considerably. In contrast, the surface-induced capacitive process (SCP) which contains double layer capacitance and Na+ adsorption into voids, defects, and functional groups, leads to fast Na+ diffusion and better structural stability in the long run. The contribution from DIP and SCP can be evaluated by cyclic voltammetry curves obtained at different scan rates. The relationship between peak current (i) and scan rate (v) can be summarized according to the following equation [33,34], i = a v b where a and b are adjustable values. If b equals to 0.5, the current is dominated by semi-infinite linear diffusion, whereas a value of 1 implies that the current is surface capacitance dominated. Zhang and co-workers designed a hierarchical layered graphene/amorphous carbon composite anode and quantitatively evaluated the contributions of both DIP and SCP [35]. The multi-layered structure exhibited a reversible capacity of 120 mAh g−1 at a current density of 10 A g−1 and 142 mAh g−1 at a current density of 0.5 A g−1 after 2500 cycles. They reported that both DIP and SCP could work in conjunction to deliver high capacities while SCP could tackle the poor diffusion of Na+ in high rates. Furthermore, first-principles computation techniques have provided valuable insights into the fundamental mechanisms behind sodium electrode materials during electrochemical cycling. Several density functional theory (DFT) studies have confirmed the instability of Na-graphite intercalation compounds (GICs) such as NaC6 or NaC8, which was rationalized by the low energy involved in the formation of the chemical bond between C and Na [36–38]. Wang et al. [36] calculated intercalation energy between Li, Na, K, and graphite and showed that Na-GICs were energetically unstable due to the poor charge transfer from Na to carbon atoms, which was not sufficient to cause an exothermic enthalpy of formation of the first stage of GIC of Na. Liu et al. [39] partitioned the formation process of M-graphite compounds (M= Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs) into three distinct steps, i.e., binding, straining and decohesion to understand why Na-graphite has a positive formation energy. After analysing the trend of each contribution, they concluded that the weak binding between Na and graphite results in a low cathodic voltage compared to other metals. They also predicted that prestrained graphite with expanded interlayer spacing through intercalation of other species could improve its capacity. Tsai et al. [40] proposed an ab initio model for disordered carbon to investigate the mechanism of Na intercalation. Their work revealed that a larger interlayer spacing and various point defects (mono-vacancy, divacancy, and Stone-Wales) can effectively overcome the van der Waals interaction between graphene layers and help Na intercalation by forming NaC8. 3 Preparation of graphene It is interesting to note that when compared to graphite, graphene as a 2D flexible material, has the potential to provide more active sites for carrier ions on both sides of the basal plane and at the edges [41]. Various synthesis methods have been developed to produce graphene including epitaxial growth of graphene on metal or SiC substrates [42–44], chemical vapour deposition (CVD) [45–47], chemical reduction [48,49], thermal reduction [50,51], electrochemical synthesis [52,53] and liquid phase exfoliation [54,55] (Fig. 3 a). The reduction of graphene oxide (GO) is another scalable and efficient method to produce graphene with a good yield. GO is a highly oxidized version of graphene consisting of various oxygen functional groups such as hydroxyl, carbonyl, carboxyl, and epoxy groups. The oxygen functional groups are located both at the edges and the basal plane of the graphene nanosheet, converting sp 2 bonded graphene to a combination of sp 2 and sp 3 hybridized carbon. The sp 3 regions with defects distort the intrinsic conjugated structure of graphene and decrease the overall strength and electrical conductivity of graphene. However, the presence of various functional groups in GO improves the processability and attracts a wide range of applications as a multi-functional material. In 2010, Marcano et al. [56] reported an improved version of Hummer's method [57] to produce GO from graphite with high yield and efficiency (Fig. 3b). Compared to Hummer's method, the improved method has replaced NaNO3 by increasing the amount of KMnO4 and the reaction is performed in a 9:1 mixture of H2SO4 and H3PO4. The key feature of GO is that it can be effectively reduced to a graphene-like structure by eliminating the oxygen functional groups with the recovery of the conjugated structure (Fig. 3c). When GO is reduced, it is generally known as reduced graphene oxide (rGO). Reduction of GO can be carried out either thermally or chemically. The thermal reduction of GO directly depends on the annealing temperature and the annealing atmosphere. The exfoliation of GO sheets occurs due to the sudden expansion of CO and CO2 gases which evolve into the spaces between graphene sheets. Schniepp et al. [58] reported that if the annealing temperature reaches over 750 °C, the carbon to oxygen (C/O) ratio of the resulting rGO could exceed 13, whereas when annealing was done below 750 °C, the C/O ratio was no more than 7. Li and co-workers monitored the chemical structure by XPS while changing the annealing temperature and concluded that high temperature is needed to achieve a good reduction of GO [59]. Wu et al. [60] used an arc-discharge treatment to reduce GO at a temperature above 2000 °C and the electrical conductivity of the graphene sheets was about 2000 S cm−1 with a C/O ratio of 15–18. Apart from temperature, annealing atmosphere also plays a vital role in the reduction of GO. As the etching of O2 is significantly increased at high temperatures, O2 should be eliminated during reduction. Therefore, the thermal reduction is carried out in a vacuum or in an inert atmosphere. Wu et al. [61] managed to achieve a conductivity of ∼1 × 103 S cm−1 with a C/O ratio of 14.9 by thermally annealing GO for 2 h in an Ar:H2 (1:1) mixture at a relatively low temperature of 450 °C, due to the high reducing ability of H2 at elevated temperatures. GO reduction can also be performed by the use of chemical reagents (reducing agents) at room temperature or by moderate heating. The most commonly used reducing agents are hydrazine monohydrate (N2H4), sodium borohydride (NaBH4) and hydroiodic acid (HI) [62–65]. However, precautions must be taken when using these chemicals as they are hazardous to human health and the environment, and also introduce impurities to the carbon matrix. To avoid these shortcomings, Fernandez-Merino et al. [66] reported a non-toxic GO reduction method of using vitamin C (ascorbic acid). The resulting rGO achieved an electrical conductivity of 77 S cm−1 with a C/O ratio of 12.5. Electrochemical reduction is another effective method to reduce GO, in which reduction of GO is carried out in an electrochemical cell at room temperature. The rGO film electrochemically produced by Zhou et al. [67] revealed a conductivity of 85 S cm−1 with a C/O ratio of 23.9. Another emerging environmental friendly chemical reduction route is the solvothermal reduction, where the reduction is performed inside a sealed container so that the solvent is brought up to its boiling point by increasing the pressure while heating [68–70]. Zhou et al. [68] reported a controlled hydrothermal reduction of GO route to convert GO to a stable graphene solution. During the hydrothermal reduction, overheated supercritical (SC) water acts as the reducing agent, so that the elevated pressure and temperature alter the properties of the resulting rGO significantly. Wang et al. [70] carried out a solvothermal reduction at 180 °C for 12 h using N, N-dimethylformamide as the solvent with a small amount of hydrazine, and the resulting rGO achieved a C/O ratio of 14.3. 4 Pure graphene anodes Graphite has been widely adopted in LIBs due to the reversible intercalation of Li atoms between layers with the formation of stable LiC6, which delivers a specific capacity of 372 mAh g−1. However, graphite has only recorded an extremely low capacity of 35 mAh g−1 for SIBs due to the formation of NaC64 [71], which is a result of the larger size of Na+ and high ionization potential [5,72,73]. However, Birte and Philipp [74] showed that the limitation of graphite can be overcome by reversible co-intercalation of Na+ and solvent molecule using a diglyme-based electrolyte. Their electrode exhibited a reversible capacity of ∼100 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles with a Coulombic efficiency of 99.87%. Kang's group developed an ether-based electrolyte for graphite anode which delivered a reversible capacity of ∼150 mAh g−1 with a cycle stability of 2500 cycles [75]. However, the huge volume expansion during the co-intercalation process results in the pulverization of the graphite anode, limiting its practical application. Wen et al. [76] used another approach to utilize graphite by expanding the interlayer distance up to 0.43 nm. The expanded graphite delivered a reversible capacity of 284 mAh g−1 at a current density of 0.02 A g−1 after 2000 cycles. Ding et al. [12] reported a graphene-like structure derived from peat moss, which exhibited good Na-storage performance due to large interlayer distance (0.388 nm). Cabello et al. [77] prepared expanded graphite with an interlayer distance of 3.388 Å by rapid heating of graphite bisulfate at 1400 °C, which consisted of sufficient space to co-intercalate sodium ions. The use of diglyme-based electrolyte improved the electrochemical performance of thermally expanded graphite in terms of delivering a capacity of 115 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles with a Coulombic efficiency of 96% when cycled at 1 C rate. Wang et al. [78] showed that rGO with an interlayer distance of 0.371 nm could store sodium and the anode exhibited a capacity of 174 mAh g−1 at a current density of 0.04 A g−1 and a reversible capacity of 95.6 mAh g−1 at a high current rate of 1 A g−1. The improved performance of the electrode is attributed to the unique structure of rGO, in which the interconnected nanosheets greatly reduce the diffusion length of Na ions. Chang's group produced rGO (GNS) with an interlayer distance of 0.375 nm using a modified Staudenmaier method and the anode exhibited a reversible capacity of 220 mAh g−1 at a current rate of 30 mA g−1 [79]. At a high current density of 5 A g−1, the GNS anode delivered a capacity of 105 mAh g−1. The high electro-adsorption/desorption area (surface area of 550 m2 g−1) along with the large interlayer spacing of GNS, contribute to the superior storage capacity. Although, expanded graphite and rGO showed improved electrochemical performance when compared with graphite, these materials still display lower reversible capacity than other anode materials. In this regard, Na+ storage capacity of graphene can be further enhanced by constructing unique structures, including 3D porous graphene with interconnected framework, defective graphene and heteroatom-doped graphene. 4.1 Porous graphene Along with the inherent properties of graphene, porous graphene has a clear edge over other porous carbon materials. For example, the excellent electrical conductivity can be used as a perfect current collector for the rapid diffusion of electrons/ions, while its high mechanical strength provides mechanical stability to the porous framework. When employed as an electrode, the porous framework improves the electrochemical performance of the battery due to the decreased diffusion distance for carrier ions [80,81]. These unique properties make porous graphene a highly promising anode material for SIBs. Porous graphene can be produced either by template method or template-free method [82,83]. Template method uses various inorganic and organic structures as templates for the transformation of graphene into porous graphene structures [84–90]. In the template-free approach, defects are introduced to the graphene basal plane by various methods. Chemical etching or chemical activation is one such method which has been used extensively to prepare porous carbon materials. It is an effective and relatively easy method to fabricate porous graphene sheets without using any template. KOH activation [91,92], HNO3 oxidation [93] are some of the template-free chemical activation techniques to produce abundant pores in the graphene basal plane (Fig. 4 a). Apart from using organic and inorganic species, the amphiphilic nature of GO itself can also be used to fabricate foam-like structures of macroscopic graphene via simple hydrothermal synthesis. The pore sizes of these 3D macroscopic structures are in the range of sub-micrometer to several micrometers. Due to macroscopic nature, they possess high mechanical strength, compressibility, excellent conductivity and adsorption characteristics [69,94,95]. Recently, our group demonstrated that rGO sheets could form a dense compact porous structure with thick and small pores when hydrothermal synthesis is carried out in acidic medium [95] (Fig. 4b). Furthermore, graphene hydrogels synthesized under acidic pH show high mechanical strength due to the compact dense structure consisting of thick pore walls and highly cross-linked 3D structure influenced by strong pi-pi interaction. Due to the unique interconnected pore structure with abundant percolating pathways connecting isolated sp 2 clusters, these GHs exhibit high electrical conductivity despite a low C/O ratio (∼6). First-principles studies showed that the Na capacity of graphene can be increased by introducing defects to the carbon matrix, where the enhanced adsorption of defective graphene is caused by the increased charge transfer between the adatoms and defects [96]. Xiaoting et al. developed porous graphene films by introducing defects into graphene using GO and ferric nitrate via a facile filtration method, and delivered a reversible capacity of 195 mAh g−1 at 50 mA g−1 after 50 cycles when used as an anode in SIBs [97]. The improved performance could be attributed to the special pore structure and the defects which provide extra ration sites for sodium ion storage. Luo et al. [98] synthesized holey graphene nanosheets by a modified Staudenmaier method where pores and surface functional groups were endowed on graphene sheets. The functional groups not only provide redox sites but also improve the inter layer distance, promoting Na ion accommodation. When employed as an anode material, the holey graphene sheets delivered reversible capacities of 220 mAh g−1 and 85 mAh g−1 at rates of 0.03 and 10 A g−1 respectively. N-doped 3D bubble-like porous graphene was synthesized via a simple template directed method using polystyrene nanospheres, followed by thermal treatment at 700 °C in a N2 atmosphere [99]. The 3D porous structure can offer rapid pathways for ion transport and accommodate large volume change during charge/discharge cycles. The as-synthesized porous graphene anode delivered a high specific capacity of 310 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at a current density of 0.2 A g−1. A 3D porous structure with a wide pore size distribution is extremely effective as an anode material, since micro/mesopores offer a large surface area for electrochemical reaction while marcopores offer rapid diffusion pathways for carrier ions [100]. Liu et al. [101] synthesized a 3D porous architecture of graphene nanowires anchored to 3D graphene foam via a template strategy involving self-assembly of graphene sheets, removal of polystyrene spheres (PS) template and thermal activation. The binder free anode exhibited a reversible capacity of 301 mAh g−1 over 1000 cycles at a rate of 1 C and a reversible capacity of 200 mAh g−1 even at a high rate of 20 C. The enhanced performance could be attributed to the multi-dimensional conductive network formed by the graphene nanowire distribution on graphene foam, the expansible graphene interlayer distance enabling rapid ion insertion/extraction and the light-weight binder-free anode with high energy density. Yan and his co-workers designed a sandwich-like nanocomposite using porous carbon on both sides of graphene, and the composite anode delivered a specific capacity of 250 mAh g−1 over 1000 cycles at a current density of 1 A g−1 [102] (Fig. 4c). Zhang et al. reported a template strategy to produce 3D porous graphene grids (PGGs) which consist of several stacking graphene structure by employing Ag nanoparticles [103]. The PGGs exhibited a specific capacities of 160 mAh g−1 at a current density of 50 mAh g−1 and 112 mAh g−1 at a current density of 1 Ah g−1 after 1000 cycles. The excellent electrochemical performance can be attributed to the porous structure with ultrahigh surface area. 4.2 Heteroatom doped-graphene Heteroatom-doped graphene has also been widely explored as an anode material for SIBs and a significant development has been achieved [104,105]. Doping graphene with heteroatoms can modulate its physiochemical and electronic properties significantly. The introduction of a heteroatom to the hexagonal carbon matrix of graphene causes structural and electronic alterations, leading to modifications in charge transport, band gap, thermal stability, optical and magnetic properties. The changes in the properties depend on the type of dopants, location, bonding configuration, and the concentration. Heteroatom doping of graphene can be achieved by various methods including CVD [106–108], ball milling [109,110], thermal annealing [111,112] and hydrothermal process [113,114]. Since boron (B) and nitrogen (N) have similar atomic sizes compared to carbon (C), it is relatively easy to incorporate them into the graphene basal plane. Wu et al. [106] produced B-doped graphene with a doping level of 4.3 at% and N-doped graphene with a doping level of 4.8% by a CVD technique using boric acid and urea as solid precursors respectively. B-doping was also performed by Li and his co-workers by using ethanol as the carbon source and boron powder as the precursor [115]. Two bonding configurations of B atoms can be observed in B-doped graphene produced by CVD: boron-silane (BC4) and graphitic boron (BC3). BC3 can be considered as the most commonly observed configuration whereas BC4 is obtained due to defects and edge sites. B with an electronic configuration of (2s 22p 1), forms sp 2 hybridization in the carbon lattice and lacks one electron compared to carbon. The electron-deficient nature of B induces a p-doping effect with a downshift of the Fermi level. Wei et al. [116] produced N-doped graphene by a CVD method, introducing a mixture of CH4 and NH3 gases into the flow when the centre of the furnace reached 800 °C. XPS analysis revealed that N atoms were in three different bonding configurations: graphitic-N, pyridinic-N, and pyrrolic-N. The electron configuration of N (1s 22s 22p 3) makes N-doped graphene clearly different from B-doped graphene. N-doping opens a bandgap near the Dirac point imparting semiconducting properties to graphene. Graphitic-N by forming three σ-bonds with neighbouring C carbon atoms imposes the n-doping effect, whereas pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N formed at defect sites, impose the p-doping effect. In addition, incorporation of heteroatoms such as oxygen (O) [117], phosphorus (P) [118–120], sulfur (S) [121–123], fluorine (F) [124,125], chlorine (Cl) [126–128], bromine (Br) [127,129], iodine (I) [125,130] and selenium (Se) [131] has also been reported in literature. Furthermore, hybrid materials with enhanced electrochemical properties can be produced by introducing transition metals like cobalt (Co) [132–134], iron (Fe) [134–136], nickel (Ni) [135] and chromium (Cr) [136] to the graphene matrix. Li et al. [137] fabricated N and P dual-doped graphene nanosheets by pyrolysis of dried hydrogels composed of GO, polyaniline (PANi) and phytic acid. Xu and his co-workers reported the synthesis of S and N co-doped few layered graphene oxide by a CVD method using pyrimidine and thiophene as precursors [138]. Zhang et al. [139] developed a nitrogen-doped porous carbon anode by chemical activation of polypyrrole-functionalized graphene sheets with KOH (Fig. 5 a). Due to the unique compositional and structural features, it delivered a high reversible capacity of 349.7 mAh g−1 at a current density of 50 mA g−1. Xu's group developed a 3D N-doped graphene foam with 6.8 at% nitrogen doping by annealing a free-dried graphene oxide in ammonia [140]. When it was used as an anode in SIBS, it exhibited a reversible capacity of 852.6 mAh g−1 at a current density of 500 mA g−1. They compared its sodium storage performance with GO foams, rGO, and N-doped graphene, and found that N-doped 3D mesoporous structure could significantly improve the electrochemical performance. The superior performance of this anode is attributed to synergistic effects associated with the 3D porous structure, with increased interlayer distance coupled with N-doping induced defects to facilitate the diffusion of Na ions. Boron (B) doping has also been regarded as an effective dopant for carbonaceous materials due to its electronic properties and nearly equal covalent radius to carbon. Wang's group produced boron-functionalized rGO (BF-rGO) with an enlarged interlayer spacing (0.37 nm) and defect-rich structure via a one-pot hydrothermal reaction using a mixture of GO and boric acid [141] (Fig. 5b). The resultant BF-rGO anode delivered a reversible capacity of 280 mAh g−1 at a current density of 0.02 A g−1 which is significantly higher than that of rGO. An overview of heteroatom-doped graphene used as SIB anode material has been presented in Table 1 . Furthermore, first principles DFT calculations by our group have shown that graphene doping with pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, F and B improves the electrochemical sodium storage due to electronic effect which originates from electron deficient sites on the graphene basal plane (i.e. defects or electron deficient atoms) [104]. P-doping could improve the storage capacity of graphene due to the geometric effect caused by bond length mismatch. Our group also predicted that graphene doping with two different atoms (pyrrolic N and P) could further improve the electrochemical performance due to abundant adsorption sites originating from both electronic and geometric effect. Although Na+ storage ability of pristine graphene is limited, expanding the interlayer spacing, constructing 3D porous structures, introducing defects and heteroatom doping can significantly enhance the electrochemical performance of graphene. However, graphene anodes suffer from low initial Coulombic efficiency due to the formation of SEI layer and irreversible reaction between Na+ and residual functional groups of graphene [152]. Moreover, the low packing density of graphene results in low volumetric energy density [153]. Therefore, to realize the full potential, graphene is generally combined with other electrode materials, enabling considerably high Na+ storage capacities compared with pure graphene anodes. Although graphene contributes to a low capacity contribution in SIBs [154–156], it plays a critical role as an excellent supporting and conducting agent due to its superior electrical conductivity and structural stability, as well as the synergistic effect of graphene and active materials further enhances the electrochemical performance of the anode [157,158]. 5 Graphene nanocomposite anodes Recently extensive research has been carried out to discover alternative anode materials for SIBs. In order to have a better performance, an anode material should have a high specific capacity, superior rate performance, good cycling stability and reaction potential to avoid dendrite formation. According to the reaction mechanism during charge/discharge of the SIB, anode materials can be classified as intercalation (insertion) based, conversion based and alloying-based materials (Fig. 6 ). In this section, the recent progress of anodes made of graphene-based nanocomposites is reviewed, under the aforementioned classification. 5.1 Intercalation materials Similar to graphene, titanium (Ti) based materials undergo intercalation mechanism when employed as SIB anodes at low voltage. The performance of Ti-based anodes such as TiO2, NaTi2(PO4)3 and Na2Ti3O7 has been hindered due to the low conductivity and large volume variation during charging/discharging. Incorporating with a conductive material like graphene has proven to be a highly effective strategy to improve the electrochemical performance of Ti-based anodes [159–161]. Kang's group developed an anode with TiO2 anchored on N-doped graphene which showed a high reversible capacity of 405 mAh g−1 over 100 cycles at a current density of 50 mA g−1 [162]. The improved performance could be attributed to the open pore channels of N-doped graphene which facilitated the ion diffusion and electron transfer. Graphene-coupled TiO2 sandwich-like hybrid anode exhibited superior rate capability, 265, 187, 90 mAh g−1 at 50, 200, 12000 mA g−1, respectively and super long-term cyclability, 120 mAh g−1 at 500 mA g−1 for over 4300 cycles [163]. Moreover first-principles simulations demonstrated that graphene partially bonding with TiO2 could reduce the diffusion energy barrier, thus improving the Na+ intercalation process. For the first time, carbon dots were utilized as “designer additives” to prepare graphene-rich petal-like rutile TiO2 anode, where the functionalization created a petal-like structure consisting of nanoneedles [164]. TiO2 nanoneedles are advantageous for shortening Na ion diffusion pathways and ultrathin graphitic carbon significantly enhances the conductivity of the ensemble. Recently, Xu et al. prepared a 3D TiO2-graphene hybrid anode via electrostatic-interaction-induced self-assembly. Strong van der Waals forces between graphene and TiO2 not only facilitated Na+ intercalation but also enhanced the interfacial sodium storage [165]. The hybrid anode delivered exceptional long-term cycle stability of 90 mAh g−1 over 5000 cycles at a high rate of 10 C and ultrahigh rate capability up to 20 C. 5.2 Conversion materials Transition metals combine with chalcogens, chemical elements of Group VIA of the periodic table (O, S, Se and Te) to form transition metal chalcogenides (TMC) which have attracted considerable attention due to their tunable bandgap, ultrathin thickness and unique electronic and mechanical properties. TMCs store Na+ via conversion reactions according to the following mechanism, M x R y + 2 y N a + + 2 y e − ↔ x M + y N a 2 R where M = Mo, Fe, Co, Cu, Ni, Mn, W, etc. and R = O, S, Se, Te. Although TMC anodes demonstrate high reversible capacities, their rate capabilities are hindered by poor electrical conductivity. Furthermore, large volume change during discharge/charge process results in poor cycling stability. In this regard, developing hybrid anodes with graphene is an exciting approach to tackle aforementioned issues of TMC anodes. 5.2.1 Graphene/transition metal sulfides As a transition metal sulfide, MoS2 has attracted wide interest due to its unique graphene-like structure and large interlayer spacing of 6.15 Å. The Na+ storage mechanism of MoS2 consists of two stages, where Na+ intercalate into interlayers in high voltage range and then conversion reaction takes place in low voltage range [166]. The expansion of interlayer spacing can boost the intercalation and diffusion of Na+ in layered MoS2 [167]. However, the weak electrical conductivity between MoS2 layers adversely affects its practical application as SIB anode. Therefore, graphene plays a key role in hybrid structures by avoiding the stacking of MoS2 and creating an electrically conductive network. David et al. [168] synthesized a self-standing flexible anode from acid-functionalized MoS2 and rGO flakes. The composite anode delivered a capacity of 338 mAh g−1 at the first cycle and remained at 218 mAh g−1 after 20 cycles at a constant current density of 25 mA g−1. Furthermore, static uniaxial tension tests revealed a high mechanical strength of 2–3 MPa and high failure strain (∼2%). A novel anode material composing of 3D graphene microspheres coated with few-layered MoS2 by a one-pot spray pyrolysis process, exhibited a discharge capacity of 322 mAh g−1 after 600 cycles at a current density of 1.5 A g−1 with a high Coulombic efficiency of 99.98% (Fig. 7 a,b) [169]. The reduced stacking of MoS2 layers eases the strain and reduces the barrier for Na insertion while the 3D structure of porous graphene offers voids for volume expansion and fast electron transfer pathways during cycling. Che et al. developed a hierarchical MoS2-rGO anode where MoS2 nanosheets were perpendicularly anchored on both sides of rGO [170]. The hybrid anode with a MoS2 loading of 92% delivered a high reversible capacity of 420 mAh g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1. A sandwich like structure with MoS2 nanosheets perpendicularly connecting with rGO through direct coupling, was synthesized by a facile method consisting of in situ growth of MoS2 on rGO and amorphous carbon coverage step ( Fig. 7c,d) [171]. The vertical structure provided more active sites and short diffusion pathways for Na+, leasing to fast reaction kinetics. The hybrid anode showed superior reversible capacity of 520 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 after 110 cycles. To provide more diffusion channels for Na, various nanostructured MoS2-rGO composite anodes with improved performance have been designed [172–174]. Cobalt sulfides including CoS [175], CoS2 [176] and Co3S4 [177] have been used as SIB anodes owing to their good chemical, physical and mechanical stability. However, poor electrical conductivity and pulverization due to repetitive volume expansion impede their practical application. Combining with graphene is one solution to avoid their aggregation tendency and enhance electrochemical performance. Zhao et al. fabricated CoS nanoflowers wrapped in reduced graphene oxide by a self-assembly approach and CoS@rGO hybrid anode delivered a high reversible capacity of 620 mAh g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1. The rGO sheets greatly increased the kinetic properties of CoS by avoiding the pulverization of nanoparticles and maintaining the electrode integrity [178]. Using an efficient in situ solvothermal technique, 10 nm thick CoS nanoplates were uniformly grown on rGO frames with strong adhesion to provide a structurally stable host for Na ion transport [179]. Due to the 2D conductive network and ultrathin CoS nanoplates, the hybrid anode demonstrated an extraordinarily cycle stability of 420 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1 after 1000 cycles. Carbon coated CoS anchored on rGO (CoS@rGO@C) composite was synthesized by a simple solvothermal reaction and subsequent carbon coating process [180]. Owing to synergistic effect of conductive rGO network and extra outer carbon coating, the as-prepared hybrid anode demonstrated superior reversible capacity of 706 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1. 5.2.2 Graphene/transition metal oxides Fe2O3 has been demonstrated as one of the most promising anode materials for SIBs due to its high theoretical capacity, high abundance and non-toxicity. For the first time Valvo et al. [181] reported nanostructured Fe2O3 as a potentially viable anode for SIBs, and the conversion reaction was proposed as, F e 2 O 3 + 6 N a + + 6 e − ↔ 2 Fe + 3 N a 2 O Incorporation of graphene into Fe2O3 nanostructures has greatly improved the electrochemical performance of the electrode with satisfactory sodium storage properties due to the synergistic effect [182–186]. As reported by Kong et al. [182], α-Fe2O3 nanorod/rGO nanosheets composite anode fabricated using a scalable hydrothermal approach demonstrated a Na storage capacity of 332 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C over 300 cycles with long term cycling stability. The direct growth of 1D α-Fe2O3 nanorod arrays on rGO nanosheets prevent the restacking of graphene sheets, further improving the reversible capacity of the electrode. The loosely porous structure reduces the resistance and improves the diffusion of ion and electron transfer which would improve the rate capability. Li's group successfully synthesized amorphous Fe2O3/graphene composite nanosheets (Fe2O3@GNS) via a facile approach, where Fe2O3 with 5 nm diameter were uniformly anchored on graphene surface by strong CO-Fe oxygen bond (Fig. 8 a) [187]. At a current density of 2000 mA g−1, Fe2O3@GNS composite anode showed a specific capacity of 110 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles (Fig. 8b). Spinel Co3O4 can store Na+ via conversion reaction with a theoretical capacity of 890 mAh g−1 [188]. However, the high theoretical capacity is affected by the large particle volume variation during charge/discharge which leads to rapid fade in material properties. Sun's group combined graphene with mesoporous Co3O4 particles and the hybrid anode ensured a good capacity (523.5 mAh g−1) and good cycle stability at 25 mA g−1 after 50 cycles [189]. Kim et al. experimentally verified for the first time that large voltage hysteresis during conversion and reconversion reactions is caused by the formation of an intermediate phase (CoO1− x ) (Fig. 8c) [190]. Their Co3O4-graphene nanoplatelet hybrid anode delivered a high capacity of 756 mAh g−1 with good reversibility (Fig. 8d,e). When combined with an Na4Fe3(PO4)2(P2O7) cathode in a full cell, it delivered an energy of 96 Wh kg−1. 5.2.3 Graphene/transition metal phosphides Transition metals such as Co, Ni and Fe have been combined with P to form metal phosphides such as CoP [191], Ni2P [192] and FeP [193]. Little attention has been paid to phosphides due to their complex synthesis techniques. Most reported phosphides are generally synthesized in elevated temperatures with the use of organic solvents and in high temperatures it is challenging to control the morphology of nanostructures. During full sodiation metal phosphide, M-P (where M= Co, Ni, Fe) electrodes undergo conversion reactions and form Na3P. Although metal phosphides exhibit high theoretical capacities, they suffer from huge volume variation and fast capacity fading due to phase decomposition. Therefore, electrochemical performance of these materials can be improved by developing graphene based nanocomposites [194–196]. Li and co-workers fabricated a unique core-shell structured CoP@FeP microcubes interconnected via rGO nanosheets via a low-temperature phosphorization process (Fig. 8f) [197]. The interconnected rGO nanosheets build a conductive highway, enhancing charge transfer kinetics as well as act as shielding layers to relieve the volume expansion during phase transformation. The nanocomposite anode delivered a final capacity of 456.2 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at a current density of 100 mA g−1 (Fig. 8g). Yin et al. developed core-shell structured Ni2P@C nanoparticles embedded inside a 3D interconnected graphene aerogel and the hybrid anode showed excellent electrochemical performance by retaining a capacity of 124.5 mAh g−1 over 2000 cycles at a high current density of 1 A g−1 [198]. The graphene aerogel consisting of abundant pores and large surface area provides easy channels for Na+ transfer and limits the contact between the electrode and the electrolyte. Furthermore, it builds a conductive matrix along the electrode as well as prevents the aggregation and pulverization of Ni2P nanoparticles. 5.2.4 Other conversion anodes Besides transition metal sulfides, oxides and phosphides, transition metal selenides [199] and tellurides [200] store Na+ via conversion reactions. Wu et al. prepared Tremella-like CoSe-rGO hybrid with improved electrical conductivity and mechanical stability by forming stable C-Se bonds [201]. The C-Se bonds with remarkable mechanical stretching, supress the dissolution of Se and mitigate the volume expansion during charge-discharge process. The CoSe-rGO anode exhibited a high reversible capacity of 400.8 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1 after 100 cycles. 5.3 Alloying materials Alloy anodes have the ability to store a large amount of Na+ at a low sodiation potential making them materials with high specific capacities and safety characteristics. The general equation for the alloying mechanism is as follows, M + x N a + + x e − ↔ N a x M Where, M = Sn, Sb, Bi, etc. However due to the high Na+ storage capacity, alloy anodes suffer from huge volume expansion and contraction during sodiation and desodiation, leading to a substantial build-up of stress under geometrical constraints of the battery design. Therefore, incorporation of graphene has proved to be an effective strategy to overcome this critical issue. High mechanical strength of graphene provides structural stability to the alloy anode while superior electrical conductivity improves the electron transportation in the electrode. Sn is one of the promising SIB anode materials with a theoretical charge capacity of 847 mAh g−1 as it has the ability to alloy with up to 3.75 Na [202]. However a huge volume expansion (420%) from Sn to Na15Sn4 results in pulverization of active materials and loss of electrical contact with current collector, leading to a drastic drop in capacity [203]. The cycling stability could be improved by anchoring Sn nanoparticles in graphene in which the carbon matrix buffers the volume change effectively and inhibit the aggregation of particles. Jeon et al. prepared a porous scaffold of rGO and graphene via a camera flash reduction technique to host Sn [204]. The porous framework with large free spaces accommodates the Sn volume change and mechanical stability. Hence, the composite anode demonstrated a high reversible capacity of 615 mAh g−1 with stable capacity retention over 84% after 50 cycles. Sn and Sb based oxides store Na+ via the combined conversion and alloying reactions. Patra's group employed supercritical CO2 fluid to synthesize 1 nm sized SnO2 particles on graphene nanosheets and CNTs [205]. SnO2 particles were uniformly dispersed and tightly connected to carbon framework, improving the electrochemical properties of the anode. High electronic conductivity and high surface area significantly enhanced Na+ transport and buffering SnO2 volume change. To further supress the agglomeration of SnO2 nanoparticles and buffer the large volume change, Chen et al. used a green synthetic strategy to grow SnO2 nanoparticles uniformly on graphene sheets via Sn-O-C bonding [206]. Recently, porphyrin derivative was used as an interfacial linker to construct SnO2 nanocrystals anchored on N and S-doped graphene via a layer-by-layer technique [207]. Due to the bonding effect and improved electrical conductivity, the hybrid anode demonstrated high initial capacity of 791.7 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and high reversible capacity of 180.2 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 0.5 A g−1. Su et al. [208] designed a SnO2@graphene nanocomposite via an in situ hydrothermal synthesis approach where FESEM and TEM images confirmed the homogenous distribution of octahedral SnO2 nanocrystals (∼60 nm in size) on graphene nanosheets. SnO2 reacts with Na based on a reversible alloying reaction and generates a Na-Sn alloy according to the following reaction [209,210], 4 Sn O 2 + 31 N a + + 31 e − → N a 15 S n 4 + 8 N a 2 O The nanocomposite demonstrated a high reversible capacity of 700 mAh g− 1 over 100 cycles at a current density of 20 mA g− 1. Xie and co-workers synthesized SnS2 nanoplatelet@graphene nanocomposites with a unique two-dimensional platelet-on-sheet nanoarchitecture, and when applied as an anode, it achieved a discharge capacity of 1339 mAh g− 1 in the first cycle and an initial reversible capacity of 725 mAh g− 1 at 20 mA g− 1 [211]. The improved performance could be credited to the synergistic effects of the SnS2/graphene hybrid nanostructure, in which graphene improves the electrical conductivity and accommodates the volume change of SnS2 during charge/discharge. A layered SnS2-rGO composite was prepared by a facile hydrothermal route from a mixture of SnCl4, thioacetamide (TAA) and GO [212]. The SnS2-rGO anode delivered a specific capacity of 500 mAh g− 1 at 1 A g− 1 even after 400 charge-discharge cycles. SnS nanoparticles electrostatically anchored on 3D N-doped graphene delivered a capacity retention of 87.1% for 1000 cycles at 2 A g− 1 with a capacity of 509.9 mAh g− 1 [213]. The strong affinity of 3D N-doped graphene to SnS and to its discharge products preserve the structural integrity, resisting the electrode pulverization and aggregation of active material during cycling. Zhou et al. [214] found that the hexagonal-SnS2 phase could be transformed into the orthorhombic-SnS phase after an annealing step in argon atmosphere (Fig. 9 a). The as-prepared SnS@graphene hybrid nanostructure delivered an excellent specific capacity of 940 mAh g− 1 and rate capability of 492 and 308 mAh g− 1 after 250 cycles at 810 and 7290 mA g− 1, respectively (Fig. 9b). Sb stands out as a desirable candidate for SIBs due to its high theoretical capacity of 660 mAh g− 1 to form Na3Sb and a safe operating potential of ∼0.4 V vs. Na+/Na [215]. Hu et al. reported a chemically coupled Sb- multilayer graphene hybrid, in which the Sb-O-C bond formed an intimate contact between Sb and graphene (Fig. 9c) [216]. The uniform distribution of Sb and the conductive and flexible graphene not only enhance Na+ diffusion but also stabilize the SEI layer during cycling (Fig. 9d). Using a facile top-down strategy, Qin's group prepared SnSb alloy nanoconfined 3D N-doped porous graphene composite, in which N-doped graphene boxes were firmly embedded with ultra-small SnSb nanocrystals [217]. The robust connections between graphene and as well as the in-plane confinement of SnSb by graphene nanosheets, highly enhance the structural integrity and electron conductivity of the electrode. The hybrid anode maintained a specific capacity above 400 mAg h−1 after 100 cycles at a current density of 0.1 A g− 1. Sb2O4 possesses a high theoretical capacity of 1227 mAh g− 1 as it accommodates Na+ through conversion followed by alloying reaction. The combined reaction proceeds as follows, S b 2 O 4 + 8 N a + + 8 e − → 2 Sb + 4 N a 2 O 2 Sb + 6 N a + 6 e − → 2 N a 3 Sb However, the practical application of Sb2O4 is limited as the conversion reaction suffers from large voltage hysteresis, low reversibility and high redox potential [218]. To resolve these issues, Ramakrishnan et al. fabricated Sb2O4@rGO nanocomposite anode where the nanowrinkled rGO nanosheets acted as a template for anchoring Sb2O4 particles cycling and effectively alleviating the strain due to volume expansion [219]. At a current density of 0.6 A g−1, composite anode delivered a reversible capacity of 626 mAh g−1. Zhou et al. reported a facile amorphous-to-crystalline strategy to synthesize a densely packed Sb2O3 nanosheet-graphene aerogel [220]. Due to the synergistic effects of densely packed Sb2O3 nanosheets and graphene aerogel with a robust support to both structural and electrochemical stability, the hybrid anode displayed a high capacity of 657.9 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 even after 100 cycles. Phosphorous (P) exhibits a high theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh g−1 due to its low molecular weight and high electron transferred number (3e−). The allotropes of P, amorphous red P and orthorhombic black P have been widely investigated as SIB anode materials. The low electrical conductivity (1 × 10−14 S cm−1) and huge volume expansion (∼490%) of red P retards the practical application of an anode [221]. Pei et al. designed composites of P nanoparticles encapsulated in graphene scrolls (P-G) and loaded on planar graphene sheets (P/G) [222]. The P-G composite anode showed a high capacity of 2355 mAh g−1 with a capacity retention of 92.3% over cycles as the scroll structure with full encapsulation of P could effectively confine the volume change. Black P closely resembles graphite and exhibits a good electrical conductivity of ∼3 S cm−1. However, its poor cycling performance caused by large anisotropic volume change needs to be improved [154]. Liu's group fabricated 4-nitrobenzene-diazonium modified black P chemically bonded with reduced graphene oxide (RGO) hybrid, which showed a high reversible capacity of 1472 mAh g–1 at current density of 0.1 A g–1 in the 50th cycle [223]. The interaction between black P and graphene improves the stability of the electrode while the enlarged channel between P and graphene stores more Na+, improving the cycle performance. Ji's group reported a sandwich-structured black P-graphene composite with the simultaneous introduction of P-C and P-O-C bonds through chemical activation [224]. The composite anode delivered a high specific capacity of 2311 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 with a capacity retention of 83.9% after 100 cycles, which can attributed to the flexible space created by graphene, alleviating the volume expansion of P. Sn and P can be integrated with each other to form a promising anode, Sn4P3 which has the advantages of Sn (good electrical conductivity) and P (high capacity). Sn4P3/rGO hybrids were synthesized through an in situ low-temperature solution-based phosphorization reaction route [225]. The hybrid anode with a 3D microporous architecture delivered an excellent reversible capacity of 656 mAh g− 1 at a current density of 100 mA g− 1 over 100 cycles. Employing a facile mechanochemical method, Xu et al. synthesized a Sn4P3-P (Sn:P = 1:3) @graphene nanocomposite with a high-rate capacity retention of >550 mAh g− 1 at 1 A g− 1 over 1000 cycles. The strong interactions between P and graphene (P-O-C bond) maintain good electrical conduction while graphene matrix prevents the segregation issue and also accommodates the large volume expansion upon Na+ uptake. Apart from the aforementioned contents there are many nanomaterials which have been integrated with graphene and evaluated as anodes for SIBs. The electrochemical performance along with the synthesis of the reported graphene based nanocomposite anodes are summarized in Table 2 . 6 Conclusions and future prospects With the recent interest in developing high-performance SIB anode materials, graphene has received increased attention. Despite its exceptional chemical and physical properties, the electrochemical performance as a SIB anode material is adversely affected due to low specific capacity and the tendency to stack together during electrode fabrication, resulting in poor sodium ion accessibility. To overcome these limitations, the construction of 3D porous graphene nanostructures and the introduction of defects and heteroatoms are found to be extremely effective. Transforming 2D graphene into a 3D interconnected porous framework with a well-defined hierarchical structure can significantly improve the electrical conductivity. The porous structure not only provides more active sites to facilitate rapid electron/ion transport, but also improves the mechanical strength to buffer volume expansion during cycling. Na storage capacity can be further enhanced by introducing defects and heteroatoms onto graphene sheets due to modified physiochemical and electronic properties and increased active sites. Moreover, co-doping strategy is expected to achieve even better Na storage capacity due to the synergistic effect. However, low packing density of graphene may lead to a low energy density. Low initial Coulombic efficiency is another problem which is due to the formation of SEI layer and irreversible reaction between Na+ and residual oxygen-functional groups of graphene. Therefore, combining graphene as a supporting and conducting agent with other nanomaterials to form composite anodes, is an effective approach to improve the overall performance. These nanomaterials act as “spacers” to prevent inter-sheet restacking and aggregation of graphene and nanoparticles. The high surface area graphene improves the electrical conductivity of the 3D structure, provides ample active sites for Na+ storage and shortens the distance for ion/electron diffusion. Furthermore, flexible graphene sheets accommodate the volume effect, thus resisting the electrode pulverization and ensuring a stable formation of the solid electrolyte interphase. Although tremendous advancements in graphene based anode materials for SIBs have been achieved, some areas deserve further investigation. Transforming 2D graphene into a 3D porous structure increases the surface area and favour ion/electron diffusion, but reduces the energy density. Moreover, 3D porous graphene has inferior mechanical strength and the synthesis techniques are often quite complicated. Introducing defects on graphene increases the active sites for Na storage, although it drastically reduces the electrical conductivity. Introduction of heteroatoms to graphene alters the physiochemical and electronic properties significantly, leading to enhanced Na storage ability. However, still it is a challenge to precisely control the doping of graphene. Therefore, further studies are required to develop new and controllable synthesis of various graphene nanostructures with optimum electrochemical performance. It is necessary to explore how the interactions between graphene and nanomaterials could affect the performance of the anode. When designing graphene based nanocomposites, it is essential to optimize the mass loading, particle size and morphology of the nanomaterials to achieve improved performance. Still it is a challenge to develop graphene based anodes with high efficiency and long term cyclability to implement in practical SIBs. The storage mechanisms in SIBs are complex and should be further investigated via in situ technologies (electron microscopy, XRD, Raman and synchrotron). The extent of research and tremendous progress made during recent years towards the development of graphene based anode materials for SIBs, suggests that there is a bright future for the commercial application of this material. With more pioneering work towards in-depth understanding and rational design of anodes, sodium-ion batteries with superior performance could be realized. Kimal Chandula Wasalathilake is a postdoctoral research associate in the School of Chemistry, Physics and Mechanical Engineering, Queensland University of Technology, Australia. He received his PhD from Queensland University of Technology in 2018. His-current research interests are carbon-based nanomaterials, electrochemical energy storage and density functional theory simulations. Henan Li was born in Qiqihar and studied in Southeast University where he passed his PhD with Prof. S. Liu. He is a Professor at the Jiangsu University, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering. His-research interest consists in the development of novel, highly functional materials and nanostructures on the electro/photo-catalysis related studies and applications in electric energy conversion and storage. Li Xu received her BS and Ph.D. degrees in 2009 and 2014 (with Professor Leigang Wang), both from the Jiangsu University, China. She is an associate Professor at the Jiangsu University and carrying on research associate at the Griffith University (Australia). She has published more than 100 papers with over 2600 citations (h-index: 26). Her research interests focus on design and synthesis of functional nanomaterials for electric energy conversion and storage. Cheng Yan received his PhD from the University of Sydney in 1998. He is currently a Professor in the School of Chemistry, Physics and Mechanical Engineering, Queensland University of Technology, Australia. His-main research interests include composites, nanomaterials, nanomechanics, and advanced material interfaces.

coredata.dc:description: Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have emerged as a promising alternative to Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) for energy storage applications, due to abundant sodium resources, low cost, and similar electrochemical performance. However, the large radius of Na+ and high molar mass compared to Li+, result in large volume strain during charge/discharge and low reversible capacity and poor cycling stability. Due to exceptional physical and chemical properties, graphene has attracted increasing attention as a potential anode material for SIBs. When integrated with other nanomaterials in electrodes, graphene can improve the electrical conductivity, accommodate the large volume change and enhance reaction kinetics. This paper provides a systematic review of recent progress in the application of graphene based anodes for SIBs, with a focus on preparation, structural configuration, Na+ storage mechanism and electrochemical performance. Additionally, some challenges and future perspectives are provided to improve the sodium storage performance of graphene based electrodes.
